content:
One would think that one-object monoidal categories are commutative monoids. Well not quite! You also get some bizarre garbage.

Let (M,⊗,1)(M,\otimes, 1)(M,⊗,1) be a monoidal category with exactly one object. Then by the argument shown here, EndM(1)\text{End}_M(1)EndM​(1) is a commutative monoid under ∘\circ∘, which coincides with ⊗\otimes⊗. What happens to the associator and unitors? Since there is only one object, they are α,λ,ρ∈EndM(1)\alpha,\lambda,\rho\in\text{End}_M(1)α,λ,ρ∈EndM​(1). The pentagon identity reduces to α3=α2\alpha^3=\alpha^2α3=α2 which implies α=1\alpha=1α=1. The triangle identity reduces to λα=ρ\lambda\alpha=\rhoλα=ρ, which implies λ=ρ\lambda=\rhoλ=ρ. Let m≔λ=ρm\coloneqq \lambda=\rhom:=λ=ρ. So, metonymically denoting EndM(1)\text{End}_M(1)EndM​(1) by MMM, our structure is completely determined by a pair (M:CommMon,m∈M)(M:\text{CommMon},m\in M)(M:CommMon,m∈M).

Now, what is a strong monoidal functor between such structures (M,m)(M,m)(M,m) and (N,n)(N,n)(N,n)? First of all, it is a commutative monoid homomorphism F:M→NF:M\to NF:M→N of course. But then we also need invertible ε,μ∈N\varepsilon,\mu\in Nε,μ∈N satisfying some equations, see nLab. These equations reduce to εμF(m)=n\varepsilon\mu F(m)=nεμF(m)=n. This means that the extra garbage, namely the mmm and nnn, might prevent an otherwise perfectly fine monoid homomorphism from being a strong monoidal functor, if it turns out that there is no invertible x∈Nx\in Nx∈N such that xF(m)=nxF(m)=nxF(m)=n.

Finally, what is a monoidal natural transformation between two such functors (F,η,ε)(F,\eta,\varepsilon)(F,η,ε) and (F′,η′,ε′)(F',\eta',\varepsilon')(F′,η′,ε′)? It is an element f∈Nf\in Nf∈N such that the diagrams in the nLab commute --- one of these is fε=ε′f\varepsilon=\varepsilon'fε=ε′, which forces fff to be invertible, and the other is fμ=μ′f2f\mu=\mu'f^2fμ=μ′f2, which, since fff is invertible, forces fμ′=μf\mu'=\mufμ′=μ. Thus εμ=ε′μ′\varepsilon\mu=\varepsilon'\mu'εμ=ε′μ′. Moreover, all monoidal transformations between strong monoidal functors between one-object monoidal categories are invertible.

Thus strong monoidal functors (M,m)→(N,n)(M,m)\to (N,n)(M,m)→(N,n) modulo isomorphism are essentially homomorphisms F:M→NF:M\to NF:M→N and invertible x∈Nx\in Nx∈N such that xF(m)=nxF(m)=nxF(m)=n.

Does anyone have any intuition as to what this extra garbage is doing? Is there a good reason that the "one-object monoidal category = commutative monoid" folklore fails? Or does it mean that our elementary definitions are somehow wrong?
The correct slogan is not "one-object monoidal categories are commutative monoids" but "pointed connected monoidal categories are commutative monoids".
In other words, the category of commutative monoids should not be expected to be equivalent to a full sub-2-category of MonCat, but of the coslice 2-category 1/MonCat1 / \mathrm{MonCat}1/MonCat.
This gets rid of the extra garbage.

So I just realized that I made a mistake, "one-object monoidal category = commutative monoid" actually works. The following is incorrect:

These equations reduce to εμF(m)=n\varepsilon\mu F(m)=nεμF(m)=n. This means that the extra garbage, namely the mmm and nnn, might prevent an otherwise perfectly fine monoid homomorphism from being a strong monoidal functor, if it turns out that there is no invertible x∈Nx\in Nx∈N such that xF(m)=nxF(m)=nxF(m)=n.

since both mmm and nnn are invertible, so there will always be a unique xxx such that xF(m)=nxF(m)=nxF(m)=n. Thus, up to isomorphism, we can ignore mmm. Similarly, a morphism of one-object monoidal categories decomposes xxx into εμ\varepsilon\muεμ. But the particular decomposition is not preserved by 2-isomorphism: up to 2-isomorphism, a morphism does not decompose xxx --- it is simply a morphism F:M→NF:M\to NF:M→N.
I did start working out the category that you suggested @Mike Shulman and it seems to work too but I have not finished. Why did you intuit that it was better?
This, and its generalizations, is a well-known issue.
I've read Mike talk about this before, when Cheng and Gurski first released their papers on the "extra garbage" problem.
So Mike can answer how he first intuited it.
E.g. it's discussed in section 5.6 of Lectures on n-categories and cohomology.
And, for Cheng and Gurski's work, try The periodic table of n-categories for low dimensions II: degenerate tricategories and the previous paper.

That was so long ago I don't know if I could definitely reconstruct my thought processes, but probably it came from homotopy theory, where pointed spaces and their loopings and deloopings are a standard object to study.

I didn't remember that the extra garbage does actually disappear for one-object monoidal categories, but as you can see from Cheng and Gurski's papers, there are other cases where it doesn't disappear even up to equivalence, unless you take the pointed perspective.

Another incarnation of this phenomenon: monoids don't precisely correspond to 1-object categories since the former form a 1-category and the latter form a 2-category. Again, considering "pointed" 1-object categories, however redundant that may seem, gets rid of the 2-cells, and we get a 1-category.

Jonas Frey said:

Another incarnation of this phenomenon: monoids don't precisely correspond to 1-object categories since the former form a 1-category and the latter form a 2-category. Again, considering "pointed" 1-object categories, however redundant that may seem, gets rid of the 2-cells, and we get a 1-category.

But this discrepancy could also be viewed in a positive light, as revealing that monoids are actually a 2-category, with a 2-morphism η:f⇒g:M→N\eta:f\Rightarrow g:M\to Nη:f⇒g:M→N as an element of NNN such that (∀m∈M)(ηf(m)=g(m)η)(\forall m\in M)(\eta f(m)=g(m)\eta)(∀m∈M)(ηf(m)=g(m)η).

I guess that this is like the monoid version of the group story: there's an equivalence of (2,1)(2,1)(2,1)-categories between groups and pointed connected groupoids (loop and deloop: Ω\OmegaΩ and B\mathbb{B}B). Or there's a similar (2,1)(2,1)(2,1)-equivalence between GGG-actions on sets and 000-truncated groupoids over BG\mathbb{B}GBG.

Joshua Meyers said:

But this discrepancy could also be viewed in a positive light, as revealing that monoids are actually a 2-category, with a 2-morphism η:f⇒g:M→N\eta:f\Rightarrow g:M\to Nη:f⇒g:M→N as an element of NNN such that (∀m∈M)(ηf(m)=g(m)η)(\forall m\in M)(\eta f(m)=g(m)\eta)(∀m∈M)(ηf(m)=g(m)η).

I don't think that's a particularly useful tack to take. Most of the time when we study monoids we are interested in them as a 1-category. I think it's better to say that when we want to consider that 2-category, we replace monoids by their deloopings.

Perhaps that's true for monoids, but for groups the associated 2-category does explain some group-theoretic constructions. For example, HNN-extensions are (certain) coinserters in the 2-category of groups.
